'War of the Roses' The History Behind Roses

19/04/2023

On the run-up to Roses Chris Stapleton (he/him) reminds us of the history behind the competition

Image by Karl Moran

By Orla McAndrew

With Roses 2023 fast approaching, itâ€™s only right to recount the historical origins which bore the largest inter-university sports competition in Europe. Of course, football matches, races, and dance offs between York and Lancaster can get intense. However there was a time when the rivalry cost more than a trophy.

The Wars of the Roses, which the sports competition takes inspiration from; were a series of English civil wars between the House of York and House of Lancaster between 1455 and 1485.

The wars began with two key figures, Henry VI and Richard of York (not to be confused with the infamous Richard III). Ironically, as the wars began with a Richard and a Henry, they also ended with a Richard and a Henry.

Henry VI took the throne of England in 1422 at the young age of nine months, following on from his father Henry V. He married a Frenchwoman, Margaret of Anjou, whose ambition outshone that of her husband, who was known to be a weak king.

Henryâ€™s weakness ultimately led to a revolt in 1450, with an army of peasants led by English revolutionary Jack Cade marching on London with a list of demands. One such demand was to recall Richard of York, who had a strong claim to the throne, back to England from Ireland.

Although, eventually, the revolt was put to an end, Richard of York made his return to England by 1452. Upon Richardâ€™s return, he aimed to rid the courts of any corruption which it might have faced, starting with the Duke of Somerset.

In 1454, Henry was rendered unable to reign due to recurring mental troubles. Due to this, Richard was appointed Lord Protector of England, sending Somerset to the Tower of London.

Richardâ€™s reign, however, did not last long. In 1453, Margaret gave birth to Edward of Lancaster, whose claim to the throne was stronger than Richardâ€™s, and in February 1455 Henry recovered from his illness. Richard was thus cast out of his position, and Somerset freed.

In May 1455, the First Battle of St Albans left Henry wounded, and a prisoner of the Yorks, and Somerset dead. Queen Margaret and her son Edward thus went into exile.

With Richard reinstated as Lord Protector once more, Margaret assembled an army led by Lord Audley to bring him down. Richard, however, anticipated her move, assembling his own army commanded by Lord Salisbury to counter Margaret.

In September 1459 the two armies clashed in The Battle of Blore Heath, leaving Richard victorious, and the Lancastrians defeated once more.

Power dynamics continued to fluctuate across two battles, The Battle of Ludford Bridge 1459 and The Battle of Northampton 1460.

The Battle of Ludford Bridge saw the returning King Henry and Queen Margaret send Richard fleeing back to Ireland, their army comprised of many York deserters. This was merely a setback, as Richard swiftly regained control with The Battle of Northampton, in which Warwickâ€™s men ambushed Henryâ€™s camp.

With Henry captive, Richard came to an agreement which would place both him and his heirs as Henryâ€™s successors, as long as Henry held the crown until he died. This would be known as the Act of Accord.

As all began to seem well, Margaret raised an army to finally defeat the Yorks at the Battle of Wakefield. Richard was brutally killed, his severed head exhibited for all to see, and adorned with a paper crown.

In the winter of 1461, Richardâ€™s son Edward (not to be confused with Henry and Margaretâ€™s son Edward) picked up where his father left off, defeating the Lancastrians at the Battle of Mortimerâ€™s Cross. However, not long after this, his forces were defeated at the Second Battle of St Albans, which saw King Henry finally freed and reunited with his family.

Edward, nevertheless, was relentless. The Battle of Towton 1461, which transpired amidst a snowstorm, saw the deaths of around 28,000 men of the 50,000 who fought. Edward of York emerged victorious, King of England, with the Lancastrians fleeing to Scotland.

Queen Margaret, again, managed to overthrow King Edward IV, returning her husband to the throne in 1470. However, Edward made sure that this was the last time.

York won both the Battle of Barnett and the Battle of Tewksbury, the latter seeing the death of Henry and Margaretâ€™s only son, Edward. King Edward IV held Henry and Margaret in the Tower of London in which Henry died (1471). Margaret was released and returned home to France where she later passed away in 1482.

Not long after Margaretâ€™s passing, King Edward IV died in 1483. Edward V, his son, took the throne, and Edward IVâ€™s brother, Richard, thus became his Lord Protector.

Richard schemed to have his brotherâ€™s two children proved illegitimate, which would allow him to ascend the throne. His plot succeeded, and he was accordingly crowned King Richard III in July 1483.

To secure his position as king, Richard sent his brotherâ€™s two sons to the Tower of London, supposedly for protection, in which they vanished. This lost Richard a lot of popularity, as people began to speculate that he had ordered for their deaths, causing mystery to surround their fatesâ€™.

Two years later, in August 1485, Richard was met by Henry Tudor, the last of the Lancastrians, in the Battle of Bosworth Field. Henry, aided by France and a selection of nobles, pursued his claim to the throne, and thus bested and killed King Richard III.

Henry was pronounced King Henry VII, and married Elizabeth of York to unite the two houses. This action marked the end of the Wars of the Roses, that is until now, where the conflict is reborn annually, between the universities of York and Lancaster
